name: AsyncAPI

urls.name: Authorization header as defined in RFC7235

description:
The AsyncAPI Specification is a project used to describe and document message-driven APIs in a machine-readable format. It’s protocol-agnostic, so you can use it for APIs that work over any protocol (e.g., AMQP, MQTT, WebSockets, Kafka, STOMP, HTTP, Mercure, etc).

The AsyncAPI Specification defines a set of files required to describe such an API. These files can then be used to create utilities, such as documentation, integration and/or testing tools.

The file(s) MUST describe the operations an application accepts. For instance, consider the following AsyncAPI definition snippet:

user/signedup:
  subscribe:
    message:
      $ref: "#/components/messages/userSignUp"

It means that the application allows consumers to subscribe to the user/signedup channel to receive userSignUp messages produced by the application.

The AsyncAPI specification does not assume any kind of software topology, architecture or pattern. Therefore, a server MAY be a message broker, a web server or any other kind of computer program capable of sending and/or receiving data. However, AsyncAPI offers a mechanism called "bindings" that aims to help with more specific information about the protocol.

concepts.name: Server
concepts.description: A server MAY be a message broker that is capable of sending and/or receiving between a producer and consumer. A server MAY be a service with WebSocket API that enables message-driven communication between browser-to-server or server-to-server.

concepts.name: Application
concepts.description: An application is any kind of computer program or a group of them. It MUST be a producer, a consumer or both. An application MAY be a microservice, IoT device (sensor), mainframe process, etc. An application MAY be written in any number of different programming languages as long as they support the selected protocol. An application MUST also use a protocol supported by the server in order to connect and exchange messages.

concepts.name: Producer
concepts.description: A producer is a type of application, connected to a server, that is creating messages and addressing them to channels. A producer MAY be publishing to multiple channels depending on the server, protocol, and use-case pattern.

concepts.name: Consumer
concepts.description: A consumer is a type of application, connected to a server via a supported protocol, that is consuming messages from channels. A consumer MAY be consuming from multiple channels depending on the server, protocol, and the use-case pattern.

concepts.name: Message
concepts.description: A message is the mechanism by which information is exchanged via a channel between servers and applications. A message MUST contain a payload and MAY also contain headers. The headers MAY be subdivided into protocol-defined headers and header properties defined by the application which can act as supporting metadata. The payload contains the data, defined by the application, which MUST be serialized into a format (JSON, XML, Avro, binary, etc.). Since a message is a generic mechanism, it can support multiple interaction patterns such as event, command, request, or response.

concepts.name: Channel
concepts.description: A channel is an addressable component, made available by the server, for the organization of messages. Producer applications send messages to channels and consumer applications consume messages from channels. Servers MAY support many channel instances, allowing messages with different content to be addressed to different channels. Depending on the server implementation, the channel MAY be included in the message via protocol-defined headers.

concepts.name: Protocol
concepts.description: A protocol is the mechanism (wireline protocol or API) by which messages are exchanged between the application and the channel. Example protocols include, but are not limited to, AMQP, HTTP, JMS, Kafka, Anypoint MQ, MQTT, Solace, STOMP, Mercure, WebSocket, Google Pub/Sub.

concepts.name: Bindings
concepts.description: A "binding" (or "protocol binding") is a mechanism to define protocol-specific information. Therefore, a protocol binding MUST define protocol-specific information only.

concepts.name: Format
concepts.description:
The files describing the message-driven API in accordance with the AsyncAPI Specification are represented as JSON objects and conform to the JSON standards. YAML, being a superset of JSON, can be used as well to represent a A2S (AsyncAPI Specification) file.

For example, if a field is said to have an array value, the JSON array representation will be used:

{
   "field" : [...]
}

While the API is described using JSON it does not impose a JSON input/output to the API itself.

All field names in the specification are case sensitive.

The schema exposes two types of fields. Fixed fields, which have a declared name, and Patterned fields, which declare a regex pattern for the field name. Patterned fields can have multiple occurrences as long as each has a unique name.

In order to preserve the ability to round-trip between YAML and JSON formats, YAML version 1.2 is recommended along with some additional constraints:

  • Tags MUST be limited to those allowed by the JSON Schema ruleset
  • Keys used in YAML maps MUST be limited to a scalar string, as defined by the YAML Failsafe schema ruleset

concepts.name: File Structure
concepts.description:
An AsyncAPI document MAY be made up of a single document or be divided into multiple, connected parts at the discretion of the author. In the latter case, Reference Objects are used.

By convention, the AsyncAPI Specification (A2S) file is named asyncapi.json or asyncapi.yaml.

concepts.name: Absolute URLs
concepts.description: Unless specified otherwise, all properties that are absolute URLs are defined by RFC3986, section 4.3.

concepts.name: Correlation ID Object
concepts.description:
An object that specifies an identifier at design time that can used for message tracing and correlation.

For specifying and computing the location of a Correlation ID, a runtime expression is used.

concepts.name: Runtime Expression
concepts.description:
A runtime expression allows values to be defined based on information that will be available within the message. This mechanism is used by Correlation ID Object.

The runtime expression is defined by the following ABNF syntax:

      expression = ( "$message" "." source )
      source = ( header-reference | payload-reference )
      header-reference = "header" ["#" fragment]
      payload-reference = "payload" ["#" fragment]
      fragment = a JSON Pointer [RFC 6901](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6901)

The table below provides examples of runtime expressions and examples of their use in a value:

concepts.name: Specification Extensions
concepts.description:
While the AsyncAPI Specification tries to accommodate most use cases, additional data can be added to extend the specification at certain points.

The extensions properties are implemented as patterned fields that are always prefixed by "x-".

Field Pattern Type Description
^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$ Any Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

The extensions may or may not be supported by the available tooling, but those may be extended as well to add requested support (if tools are internal or open-sourced).

concepts.name: Data Type Formats
concepts.description:
Primitives have an optional modifier property: format. The AsyncAPI specification uses several known formats to more finely define the data type being used. However, the format property is an open string-valued property, and can have any value to support documentation needs. Formats such as "email", "uuid", etc., can be used even though they are not defined by this specification. Types that are not accompanied by a format property follow their definition from the JSON Schema. Tools that do not recognize a specific format MAY default back to the type alone, as if the format was not specified.

The formats defined by the AsyncAPI Specification are:

Common Name type format Comments
integer integer int32 signed 32 bits
long integer int64 signed 64 bits
float number float
double number double
string string
byte string byte base64 encoded characters
binary string binary any sequence of octets
boolean boolean
date string date As defined by full-date - RFC3339
dateTime string date-time As defined by date-time - RFC3339
password string password Used to hint UIs the input needs to be obscured.

schemas.name: AsyncAPI Object
schemas.description: This is the root document object for the API specification. It combines resource listing and API declaration together into one document.

fields.name: asyncapi
fields.description: Specifies the AsyncAPI Specification version being used. It can be used by tooling Specifications and clients to interpret the version. The structure shall be major.minor.patch, where patch versions must be compatible with the existing major.minor tooling. Typically patch versions will be introduced to address errors in the documentation, and tooling should typically be compatible with the corresponding major.minor (1.0.*). Patch versions will correspond to patches of this document.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Identifier of the application the AsyncAPI document is defining.

fields.name: info
fields.description: Provides metadata about the API. The metadata can be used by the clients if needed.

fields.name: servers
fields.description: Provides connection details of servers.

fields.name: defaultContentType
fields.description: Default content type to use when encoding/decoding a message's payload.

fields.name: channels
fields.description: The available channels and messages for the API.

fields.name: components
fields.description: An element to hold various schemas for the specification.

fields.name: tags
fields.description: A list of tags used by the specification with additional metadata. Each tag name in the list MUST be unique.

fields.name: externalDocs
fields.description: Additional external documentation.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: AsyncAPI Version String
schemas.description:
The version string signifies the version of the AsyncAPI Specification that the document complies to. The format for this string must be major.minor.patch. The patch may be suffixed by a hyphen and extra alphanumeric characters.

A major.minor shall be used to designate the AsyncAPI Specification version, and will be considered compatible with the AsyncAPI Specification specified by that major.minor version. The patch version will not be considered by tooling, making no distinction between 1.0.0 and 1.0.1.

In subsequent versions of the AsyncAPI Specification, care will be given such that increments of the minor version should not interfere with operations of tooling developed to a lower minor version. Thus a hypothetical 1.1.0 specification should be usable with tooling designed for 1.0.0.

schemas.name: Identifier
schemas.description:
This field represents a unique universal identifier of the application the AsyncAPI document is defining. It must conform to the URI format, according to RFC3986.

It is RECOMMENDED to use a URN to globally and uniquely identify the application during long periods of time, even after it becomes unavailable or ceases to exist.

schemas.name: Info Object
schemas.description: The object provides metadata about the API. The metadata can be used by the clients if needed.

fields.name: title
fields.description: The title of the application.

fields.name: version
fields.description: Provides the version of the application API (not to be confused with the specification version).

fields.name: description
fields.description: A short description of the application.

fields.name: termsOfService
fields.description: A URL to the Terms of Service for the API. This MUST be in the form of an absolute URL.

fields.name: contact
fields.description: The contact information for the exposed API.

fields.name: license
fields.description: The license information for the exposed API.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Contact Object
schemas.description: Contact information for the exposed API.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The identifying name of the contact person/organization.

fields.name: url
fields.description: The URL pointing to the contact information. This MUST be in the form of an absolute URL.

fields.name: email
fields.description: The email address of the contact person/organization. MUST be in the format of an email address.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: License Object
schemas.description: License information for the exposed API.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The license name used for the API.

fields.name: url
fields.description: A URL to the license used for the API. This MUST be in the form of an absolute URL.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Servers Object
schemas.description: The Servers Object is a map of Server Objects.

fields.name: ^[A-Za-z0-9_\-]+$
fields.description: The definition of a server this application MAY connect to.

schemas.name: Server Object
schemas.description: An object representing a message broker, a server or any other kind of computer program capable of sending and/or receiving data. This object is used to capture details such as URIs, protocols and security configuration. Variable substitution can be used so that some details, for example usernames and passwords, can be injected by code generation tools.

fields.name: url
fields.description: A URL to the target host. This URL supports Server Variables and MAY be relative, to indicate that the host location is relative to the location where the AsyncAPI document is being served. Variable substitutions will be made when a variable is named in {braces}.

fields.name: protocol
fields.description: The protocol this URL supports for connection. Supported protocol include, but are not limited to: amqp, amqps, http, https, ibmmq, jms, kafka, kafka-secure, anypointmq, mqtt, secure-mqtt, solace, stomp, stomps, ws, wss, mercure, googlepubsub.

fields.name: protocolVersion
fields.description: The version of the protocol used for connection. For instance: AMQP 0.9.1, HTTP 2.0, Kafka 1.0.0, etc.

fields.name: description
fields.description: An optional string describing the host designated by the URL.

fields.name: variables
fields.description: A map between a variable name and its value.  The value is used for substitution in the server's URL template.

fields.name: security
fields.description: A declaration of which security mechanisms can be used with this server. The list of values includes alternative security requirement objects that can be used. Only one of the security requirement objects need to be satisfied to authorize a connection or operation.

fields.name: tags
fields.description: A list of tags for logical grouping and categorization of servers.

fields.name: bindings
fields.description: A map where the keys describe the name of the protocol and the values describe protocol-specific definitions for the server.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Server Variable Object
schemas.description: An object representing a Server Variable for server URL template substitution.

fields.name: enum
fields.description: An enumeration of string values to be used if the substitution options are from a limited set.

fields.name: default
fields.description: The default value to use for substitution, and to send, if an alternate value is not supplied.

fields.name: description
fields.description: An optional description for the server variable.

fields.name: examples
fields.description: An array of examples of the server variable.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Default Content Type
schemas.description:
A string representing the default content type to use when encoding/decoding a message's payload. The value MUST be a specific media type (e.g. application/json). This value MUST be used by schema parsers when the contentType property is omitted.

In case a message can't be encoded/decoded using this value, schema parsers MUST use their default content type.

schemas.name: Channels Object
schemas.description:
Holds the relative paths to the individual channel and their operations. Channel paths are relative to servers.

Channels are also known as "topics", "routing keys", "event types" or "paths".

fields.name: {channel}
fields.description: A relative path to an individual channel. The field name MUST be in the form of a RFC 6570 URI template. Query parameters and fragments SHALL NOT be used, instead use bindings to define them.

schemas.name: Channel Item Object
schemas.description: Describes the operations available on a single channel.

fields.name: $ref
fields.description:
Allows for a referenced definition of this channel item. The referenced structure MUST be in the form of a Channel Item Object. In case a Channel Item Object field appears both in the defined object and the referenced object, the behavior is undefined. Resolution is done as defined by the JSON Reference.

Deprecated: Usage of the $ref property has been deprecated.

fields.name: description
fields.description: An optional description of this channel item.

fields.name: servers
fields.description: The servers on which this channel is available, specified as an optional unordered list of names (string keys) of Server Objects defined in the Servers Object (a map). If servers is absent or empty then this channel must be available on all servers defined in the Servers Object.

fields.name: subscribe
fields.description: A definition of the SUBSCRIBE operation, which defines the messages produced by the application and sent to the channel.

fields.name: publish
fields.description: A definition of the PUBLISH operation, which defines the messages consumed by the application from the channel.

fields.name: parameters
fields.description: A map of the parameters included in the channel name. It SHOULD be present only when using channels with expressions (as defined by RFC 6570 section 2.2).

fields.name: bindings
fields.description: A map where the keys describe the name of the protocol and the values describe protocol-specific definitions for the channel.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Operation Object
schemas.description:
Describes a publish or a subscribe operation. This provides a place to document how and why messages are sent and received.

For example, an operation might describe a chat application use case where a user sends a text message to a group. A publish operation describes messages that are received by the chat application, whereas a subscribe operation describes messages that are sent by the chat application.

fields.name: operationId
fields.description: Unique string used to identify the operation. The id MUST be unique among all operations described in the API. The operationId value is case-sensitive. Tools and libraries MAY use the operationId to uniquely identify an operation, therefore, it is RECOMMENDED to follow common programming naming conventions.

fields.name: summary
fields.description: A short summary of what the operation is about.

fields.name: description
fields.description: A verbose explanation of the operation.

fields.name: security
fields.description: A declaration of which security mechanisms are associated with this operation. Only one of the security requirement objects MUST be satisfied to authorize an operation. In cases where Server Security also applies, it MUST also be satisfied.

fields.name: tags
fields.description: A list of tags for logical grouping and categorization of operations.

fields.name: externalDocs
fields.description: Additional external documentation for this operation.

fields.name: bindings
fields.description: A map where the keys describe the name of the protocol and the values describe protocol-specific definitions for the operation.

fields.name: traits
fields.description: A list of traits to apply to the operation object. Traits MUST be merged into the operation object using the JSON Merge Patch algorithm in the same order they are defined here.

fields.name: message
fields.description: A definition of the message that will be published or received by this operation. Map containing a single oneOf key is allowed here to specify multiple messages. However, a message MUST be valid only against one of the message objects.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Operation Trait Object
schemas.description:
Describes a trait that MAY be applied to an Operation Object. This object MAY contain any property from the Operation Object, except message and traits.

If you're looking to apply traits to a message, see the Message Trait Object.

fields.name: operationId
fields.description: Unique string used to identify the operation. The id MUST be unique among all operations described in the API. The operationId value is case-sensitive. Tools and libraries MAY use the operationId to uniquely identify an operation, therefore, it is RECOMMENDED to follow common programming naming conventions.

fields.name: summary
fields.description: A short summary of what the operation is about.

fields.name: description
fields.description: A verbose explanation of the operation.

fields.name: security
fields.description: A declaration of which security mechanisms are associated with this operation. Only one of the security requirement objects MUST be satisfied to authorize an operation. In cases where Server Security also applies, it MUST also be satisfied.

fields.name: tags
fields.description: A list of tags for logical grouping and categorization of operations.

fields.name: externalDocs
fields.description: Additional external documentation for this operation.

fields.name: bindings
fields.description: A map where the keys describe the name of the protocol and the values describe protocol-specific definitions for the operation.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Parameters Object
schemas.description:
Describes a map of parameters included in a channel name.

This map MUST contain all the parameters used in the parent channel name.

fields.name: ^[A-Za-z0-9_\-]+$
fields.description: The key represents the name of the parameter. It MUST match the parameter name used in the parent channel name.

schemas.name: Parameter Object
schemas.description: Describes a parameter included in a channel name.

fields.name: description
fields.description: A verbose explanation of the parameter.

fields.name: schema
fields.description: Definition of the parameter.

fields.name: location
fields.description: A runtime expression that specifies the location of the parameter value. Even when a definition for the target field exists, it MUST NOT be used to validate this parameter but, instead, the schema property MUST be used.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Server Bindings Object
schemas.description: Map describing protocol-specific definitions for a server.

fields.name: http
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for an HTTP server.

fields.name: ws
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for a WebSockets server.

fields.name: kafka
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for a Kafka server.

fields.name: anypointmq
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for an Anypoint MQ server.

fields.name: amqp
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for an AMQP 0-9-1 server.

fields.name: amqp1
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for an AMQP 1.0 server.

fields.name: mqtt
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for an MQTT server.

fields.name: mqtt5
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for an MQTT 5 server.

fields.name: nats
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for a NATS server.

fields.name: jms
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for a JMS server.

fields.name: sns
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for an SNS server.

fields.name: solace
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for a Solace server.

fields.name: sqs
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for an SQS server.

fields.name: stomp
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for a STOMP server.

fields.name: redis
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for a Redis server.

fields.name: mercure
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for a Mercure server.

fields.name: ibmmq
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for an IBM MQ server.

fields.name: googlepubsub
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for a Google Cloud Pub/Sub server.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Message Bindings Object
schemas.description: Map describing protocol-specific definitions for a message.

fields.name: http
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for an HTTP message, i.e., a request or a response.

fields.name: ws
fields.description: Protocol-specific information for a WebSockets message.

fields.name: kafka

fields.name: anypointmq

fields.name: mqtt

fields.description: Protocol-specific information for a Google Cloud Pub/Sub message.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Message Object
schemas.description: Describes a message received on a given channel and operation.

fields.name: messageId
fields.description: Unique string used to identify the message. The id MUST be unique among all messages described in the API. The messageId value is case-sensitive. Tools and libraries MAY use the messageId to uniquely identify a message, therefore, it is RECOMMENDED to follow common programming naming conventions.

fields.name: headers
fields.description: Schema definition of the application headers. Schema MUST be of type "object". It MUST NOT define the protocol headers.

fields.name: payload
fields.description: Definition of the message payload. It can be of any type but defaults to Schema object. It must match the schema format, including encoding type - e.g Avro should be inlined as either a YAML or JSON object NOT a string to be parsed as YAML or JSON.

fields.name: correlationId
fields.description: Definition of the correlation ID used for message tracing or matching.

fields.name: schemaFormat
fields.description:
A string containing the name of the schema format used to define the message payload. If omitted, implementations should parse the payload as a Schema object. When the payload is defined using a $ref to a remote file, it is RECOMMENDED the schema format includes the file encoding type to allow implementations to parse the file correctly. E.g., adding +yaml if content type is application/vnd.apache.avro results in application/vnd.apache.avro+yaml.

Check out the supported schema formats table for more information. Custom values are allowed but their implementation is OPTIONAL. A custom value MUST NOT refer to one of the schema formats listed in the table.

fields.name: contentType
fields.description: The content type to use when encoding/decoding a message's payload. The value MUST be a specific media type (e.g. application/json). When omitted, the value MUST be the one specified on the defaultContentType field.

fields.name: name
fields.description: A machine-friendly name for the message.

fields.name: title
fields.description: A human-friendly title for the message.

fields.name: summary
fields.description: A short summary of what the message is about.

fields.name: description
fields.description: A verbose explanation of the message.

fields.name: tags
fields.description: A list of tags for logical grouping and categorization of messages.

fields.name: externalDocs
fields.description: Additional external documentation for this message.

fields.name: bindings
fields.description: A map where the keys describe the name of the protocol and the values describe protocol-specific definitions for the message.

fields.name: examples
fields.description: List of examples.

fields.name: traits
fields.description: A list of traits to apply to the message object. Traits MUST be merged into the message object using the JSON Merge Patch algorithm in the same order they are defined here. The resulting object MUST be a valid Message Object.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Message Trait Object
schemas.description:
Describes a trait that MAY be applied to a Message Object. This object MAY contain any property from the Message Object, except payload and traits.

If you're looking to apply traits to an operation, see the Operation Trait Object.

fields.name: messageId
fields.description: Unique string used to identify the message. The id MUST be unique among all messages described in the API. The messageId value is case-sensitive. Tools and libraries MAY use the messageId to uniquely identify a message, therefore, it is RECOMMENDED to follow common programming naming conventions.

fields.name: headers
fields.description: Schema definition of the application headers. Schema MUST be of type "object". It MUST NOT define the protocol headers.

fields.name: correlationId
fields.description: Definition of the correlation ID used for message tracing or matching.

fields.name: schemaFormat
fields.description: A string containing the name of the schema format/language used to define the message payload. If omitted, implementations should parse the payload as a Schema object.

fields.name: contentType
fields.description: The content type to use when encoding/decoding a message's payload. The value MUST be a specific media type (e.g. application/json). When omitted, the value MUST be the one specified on the defaultContentType field.

fields.name: name
fields.description: A machine-friendly name for the message.

fields.name: title
fields.description: A human-friendly title for the message.

fields.name: summary
fields.description: A short summary of what the message is about.

fields.name: description
fields.description: A verbose explanation of the message.

fields.name: tags
fields.description: A list of tags for logical grouping and categorization of messages.

fields.name: externalDocs
fields.description: Additional external documentation for this message.

fields.name: bindings
fields.description: A map where the keys describe the name of the protocol and the values describe protocol-specific definitions for the message.

fields.name: examples
fields.description: List of examples.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Message Example Object
schemas.description: Message Example Object represents an example of a Message Object and MUST contain either headers and/or payload fields.

fields.name: headers
fields.description: The value of this field MUST validate against the Message Object's headers field.

fields.name: payload
fields.description: The value of this field MUST validate against the Message Object's payload field.

fields.name: name
fields.description: A machine-friendly name.

fields.name: summary
fields.description: A short summary of what the example is about.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Tags Object
schemas.description: A Tags object is a list of Tag Objects.

schemas.name: Tag Object
schemas.description: Allows adding meta data to a single tag.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the tag.

fields.name: description
fields.description: A short description for the tag.

fields.name: externalDocs
fields.description: Additional external documentation for this tag.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: External Documentation Object
schemas.description: Allows referencing an external resource for extended documentation.

fields.name: description
fields.description: A short description of the target documentation.

fields.name: url
fields.description: The URL for the target documentation. This MUST be in the form of an absolute URL.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Reference Object
schemas.description:
A simple object to allow referencing other components in the specification, internally and externally.

The Reference Object is defined by JSON Reference and follows the same structure, behavior and rules. A JSON Reference SHALL only be used to refer to a schema that is formatted in either JSON or YAML. In the case of a YAML-formatted Schema, the JSON Reference SHALL be applied to the JSON representation of that schema. The JSON representation SHALL be made by applying the conversion described here.

For this specification, reference resolution is done as defined by the JSON Reference specification and not by the JSON Schema specification.

fields.name: $ref
fields.description: The reference string.

schemas.name: Components Object
schemas.description: Holds a set of reusable objects for different aspects of the AsyncAPI specification. All objects defined within the components object will have no effect on the API unless they are explicitly referenced from properties outside the components object.

fields.name: schemas
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Schema Objects.

fields.name: servers
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Server Objects.

fields.name: serverVariables
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Server Variable Objects.

fields.name: channels
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Channel Item Objects.

fields.name: messages
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Message Objects.

fields.name: securitySchemes
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Security Scheme Objects.

fields.name: parameters
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Parameter Objects.

fields.name: correlationIds
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Correlation ID Objects.

fields.name: operationTraits
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Operation Trait Objects.

fields.name: messageTraits
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Message Trait Objects.

fields.name: serverBindings
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Server Bindings Objects.

fields.name: channelBindings
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Channel Bindings Objects.

fields.name: operationBindings
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Operation Bindings Objects.

fields.name: messageBindings
fields.description: An object to hold reusable Message Bindings Objects.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Schema Object
schemas.description:
The Schema Object allows the definition of input and output data types. These types can be objects, but also primitives and arrays. This object is a superset of the JSON Schema Specification Draft 07. The empty schema (which allows any instance to validate) MAY be represented by the boolean value true and a schema which allows no instance to validate MAY be represented by the boolean value false.

Further information about the properties can be found in JSON Schema Core and JSON Schema Validation. Unless stated otherwise, the property definitions follow the JSON Schema specification as referenced here.

fields.name: discriminator
fields.description: Adds support for polymorphism. The discriminator is the schema property name that is used to differentiate between other schema that inherit this schema. The property name used MUST be defined at this schema and it MUST be in the required property list. When used, the value MUST be the name of this schema or any schema that inherits it. See Composition and Inheritance for more details.

fields.name: externalDocs
fields.description: Additional external documentation for this schema.

fields.name: deprecated
fields.description: Specifies that a schema is deprecated and SHOULD be transitioned out of usage. Default value is false.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Security Scheme Object
schemas.description:
Defines a security scheme that can be used by the operations. Supported schemes are:

  • User/Password.
  • API key (either as user or as password).
  • X.509 certificate.
  • End-to-end encryption (either symmetric or asymmetric).
  • HTTP authentication.
  • HTTP API key.
  • OAuth2's common flows (Implicit, Resource Owner Protected Credentials, Client Credentials and Authorization Code) as defined in RFC6749.
  • OpenID Connect Discovery.
  • SASL (Simple Authentication and Security Layer) as defined in RFC4422.

fields.name: type
fields.description: The type of the security scheme. Valid values are "userPassword", "apiKey", "X509", "symmetricEncryption", "asymmetricEncryption", "httpApiKey", "http", "oauth2", "openIdConnect", "plain", "scramSha256", "scramSha512", and "gssapi".

fields.name: description
fields.description: A short description for security scheme.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the header, query or cookie parameter to be used.

fields.name: in
fields.description: The location of the API key. Valid values are "user" and "password" for apiKey and "query", "header" or "cookie" for httpApiKey.

fields.name: scheme

urls.name: Authorization header as defined in RFC7235

fields.description: The name of the HTTP Authorization scheme to be used in the Authorization header as defined in RFC7235.

fields.name: bearerFormat
fields.description: A hint to the client to identify how the bearer token is formatted.  Bearer tokens are usually generated by an authorization server, so this information is primarily for documentation purposes.

fields.name: flows
fields.description: An object containing configuration information for the flow types supported.

fields.name: openIdConnectUrl
fields.description: OpenId Connect URL to discover OAuth2 configuration values. This MUST be in the form of an absolute URL.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: OAuth Flows Object
schemas.description: Allows configuration of the supported OAuth Flows.

fields.name: implicit
fields.description: Configuration for the OAuth Implicit flow.

fields.name: password
fields.description: Configuration for the OAuth Resource Owner Protected Credentials flow.

fields.name: clientCredentials
fields.description: Configuration for the OAuth Client Credentials flow.

fields.name: authorizationCode
fields.description: Configuration for the OAuth Authorization Code flow.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: OAuth Flow Object
schemas.description: Configuration details for a supported OAuth Flow

fields.name: authorizationUrl
fields.description: The authorization URL to be used for this flow. This MUST be in the form of an absolute URL.

fields.name: tokenUrl
fields.description: The token URL to be used for this flow. This MUST be in the form of an absolute URL.

fields.name: refreshUrl
fields.description: The URL to be used for obtaining refresh tokens. This MUST be in the form of an absolute URL.

fields.name: scopes
fields.description: The available scopes for the OAuth2 security scheme. A map between the scope name and a short description for it.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.

schemas.name: Security Requirement Object
schemas.description:
Lists the required security schemes to execute this operation. The name used for each property MUST correspond to a security scheme declared in the Security Schemes under the Components Object.

When a list of Security Requirement Objects is defined on a Server object, only one of the Security Requirement Objects in the list needs to be satisfied to authorize the connection.

fields.name: {name}
fields.description: Each name MUST correspond to a security scheme which is declared in the Security Schemes under the Components Object. If the security scheme is of type "oauth2" or "openIdConnect", then the value is a list of scope names. Provide scopes that are required to establish successful connection with the server. If scopes are not needed, the list can be empty. For other security scheme types, the array MUST be empty.

schemas.name: Correlation ID Object
schemas.description:
An object that specifies an identifier at design time that can used for message tracing and correlation.

For specifying and computing the location of a Correlation ID, a runtime expression is used.

fields.name: description
fields.description: An optional description of the identifier.

fields.name: location
fields.description: A runtime expression that specifies the location of the correlation ID.

fields.name: ^x-[\w\d\-\_]+$
fields.description: Allows extensions to the AsyncAPI Schema. The field name MUST begin with x-, for example, x-internal-id. The value can be null, a primitive, an array or an object. Can have any valid JSON format value.
